field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
The Ministry of Health through the Public Health Institute of Malawi (PHIM) confirmed that  as of 27th May 2025 PHIM Update Lilongwe, Mangochi and Ntcheu districts collectively recorded a total of twelve (12) confirmed cases (Lilongwe - 10, Mangochi -1 and Ntcheu -1) of Mpox, formerly known as Monkeypox. Eleven of the cases are males and one female in the age range of 2 to 41 years.
Five cases from Lilongwe and one from Mangochi district have recovered and been discharged from clinical care. Meanwhile, the remaining six cases are under clinical care—five on home isolation and one being managed at Kamuzu Central Hospital. Since August 2024, a total of 183 samples from suspected cases have been tested. Since the onset of the outbreak, no Mpox-related deaths have been reported.
field_reports.description:
Mpox is a zoonotic viral disease transmitted from animals to humans and from humans to humans. It is characterized by fever and rash. The Mpox virus spreads through contact with respiratory droplets, lesion material, body fluids, contaminated materials and surfaces which enter the body through the respiratory tract, mucous membranes and broken skin. Anyone can get infected with the Mpox virus. Children, pregnant women, people with underlying immune deficiencies and people with multiple sex partners have a higher risk of getting the disease and according to the current statistics males are at high risk and this have a negative implication as it will affect livelihoods since men are mostly bread winners. While there is no specific treatment for Mpox, treatment remains supportive and symptomatic. There is a high chance of spread among the high-risk groups in Malawi.  

However as of today 11th June 2025 Lilongwe DHO has confirmed a cumulative cases of 25 and has 11 active cases  which have been recorded in 8 Health facilities and 4 Traditional authorities> Furthermore deaths remain at 0

field_reports.summary: MWI: Epidemic - 08-2024 - Measles outbreak in Malawi
field_reports.description:
Malawi has reported measles cases in Mangochi District in the Southern Region. On 29thAugust 2024, Mangochi District Heath Office was alerted on a cluster of suspected measles cases in a village under Mkuchinga Jwambone Health Center. Six samples were collected for laboratory investigation at Kamuzu Central Hospital in Lilongwe. Three samples were confirmed positive for Measles on 9th September, 2024. The ages of the confirmed measles cases are seven months, five and seven years old. Measles, is a highly infectious viral disease characterized by a generalized rash, fever, running nose and at least cough or Coryza or red-eye. It spreads through direct contact with mouth or nasal droplets when an infected person breathes, coughs or sneezes. While the disease can affect anyone, unvaccinated or under vaccinated under five children and pregnant mothers are at high risk of contracting and developing severe form of the disease. If untreated, measles can cause serious complications like blindness or death. It is therefore, important to seek urgent medical help. There is no specific treatment for measles. The symptoms are usually mild and self-resolving within a period of about one week. 
Communities are advised to take preventive measures as the disease has the potential to affect more people. Vaccination is the most effective way to prevent measles. Ministry of Health with support from its partners including Malawi Red Cross is encouraging parents to vaccinate their children.

field_reports.description:
His Excellency Dr. Lazarus McCarthy Chakwera, President of the Republic of Malawi, has noted with grave concern the devastation that Cyclone Freddy is currently bringing to most districts in Malawi’s Southern region. President of the Republic of Malawi has exercised the powers vested in him under section 32(1) of the Disaster Preparedness and Relief Act (Cap 33:05 of the Laws of Malawi) and declared a state of disaster in the Southern Region of Malawi, particularly the areas comprising the jurisdictions of Blantyre City and District Chikwawa District Chiradzulu District Mulanje District Mwanza District Neno District Nsanje District Thyolo District Phalombe District Zomba City and District.  Accordingly, Government is already responding to the emergencies, rendering urgent assistance to all affected districts, and appealing for local and international support for all the families affected by this disaster.

As of Sunday, 12th March 2023, DCCMS had projected that there would be a 100 per cent possibility that TCF would trigger rains exceeding 150 mm on Sunday, persisting into Monday and Tuesday the 14th of March.

The torrential rains are being accompanied by damaging winds and flooding. The areas that have been affected so far are Blantyre, Chikwawa, Chiradzulu, Mulanje, Neno, Nsanje, Phalombe and Thyolo affecting a total of 19,314 people. 12,371 people have been displaced and are seeking shelter in camps.  198 people have died because of the floods while 153 people have been injured. Currently 16 people are reportedly missing.

In view of the above, the Department of Disaster Management Affairs (DoDMA) in collaboration with various humanitarian partners, has been coordinating preparedness and response interventions to reduce the impact of TCF.

Critical needs are food, shelter, safe water and NFIs.

results.summary:
Tropical Storm Freddy swept through Southern Malawi on 12 March 2023, with strong winds and heavy rains leaving the affected districts in a state of disaster and affecting the power supply throughout most of the country. Tropical Storm Freddy is set to be the longest tropical system since 1994, having weakened and re-intensified seven times over the last month.

The Malawi government has declared a state of disaster in 10 southern districts that have been hardest hit by the storm. A large number of people are reported to have been affected, of which 101.648 households (approximately 508.244 people) have been displaced with 534 camps set to accommodate the displaced, according to reports from DoDMA. The death toll, which is currently at 499 (as of 20 March 2023), is expected to rise as 427 people are still unaccounted for since some areas remain cut off due to relentless rain and fierce wind.

Our response as of the 29th of May:

The shelter sector has reached 2,699 (179%) households out of a target of 1,500 provided with emergency and temporary shelter assistance.

A total of 8,025 (160%) households have been reached with food assistance against a target of 5,000. A total of 2,800 households were reached last week with food distributions and NFIs in Zomba (1,400), and Machinga (1,200) through the support of Qatar RC.In terms of multi-purpose cash, 2,135 (43%) households have been provided with multipurpose cash grants against a target of 5,000 households. A total of 436 households were reached last week. There is a scheduled cash distribution targeting 726 households in Chikwawa scheduled for this week.

76 (32%) volunteers and staff have been trained on PFA for health and care.

7,200 mosquito nets have been distributed to 3,600 (102%) households against a target of 1,600 nets. A total of 5,600 nets were distributed last week through the Qatar RC.       

A total of 2,007 people were reached through First Aid services disaggregated as (Males - 741, females - 1266, and children – 200).

For the WASH sector, 11,879 (7%) people were reached by hygiene promotion activities (including communities and schools). 1,250 (3%) people have been provided with safe water services that meet agreed standards according to specific operational and programmatic contexts.  5 boreholes have been rehabilitated, and as per the Malawi standards, each borehole should serve a population of approximately 250 people. For PGI, 8,124 (5%) people have been reached with PGI, prevention, and response to SGBV awareness messages.

For CEA, 100% (911 queries and feedback received) of the queries/feedback received through the feedback mechanisms established were responded to. A total of 211 queries and feedback were received during last week's distributions.

A PDM was done for the households reached in the first distribution of NFIs, and the satisfaction rate was 97%.

Under Coordination and Partnerships, MRCS continues to get support from the movement (IFRC, Qatar RC, Danish RC, Belgium RC), UN agencies(IOM, WFP), and private sector players.

field_reports.description:
The Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services (DCCMS), issued a warning on Tropical Cyclone Gombe. The warning pointed out that the cyclone, which was expected to be associated with heavy rainfall exceeding
100mm in 24 hours, might trigger the occurrence of flash floods from Saturday 12th March to Sunday the 13th of March, 2022, with most parts of the southern region at risk of being affected.
Widespread floods, damages to public infrastructures and private homes as well as interruption of basic services are already being reported, as heavy rains and strong winds continue to hit the country. The department of climate change and meteorogical services issued a red warning for heavy rains and strong winds for the the districts of Mulanje, Nsanje, Chikwawa, Phalombe, Zomba, Machinga, Thyolo, Chiradzulu, Blantyre and Mangochi as districts at risk of being affected by the looming cyclone over the period between 11 and 14 March. The Inter-agency assessment team from various cluster representation has been deployed to support the district which have been affected by the cyclone Gombe.
Following the disaster, Zomba district has reported that over 2, 286 houses have been completely damaged in all the respective 7 T/As which have been affected by the disaster. The affected people have been displaced in 29 camps which have been established across the affected areas. 
In Phalombe, the situation on the ground remains critical as over 15,000HH have been affected by the disaster, The district has received reports on the camps which have been established but they are yet to verify on the actual number of the people staying at the camps as most of the access roads are still impassable to carry out a verified assessment. 
In Nsanje 2 camps have been established, many of the affected people have been displaced and have integrated themselves in the camps which were established after the effect of cyclone Ana. The integration is likely to pose a threat for congestion in the camps which may end up influencing disease breakouts and affect issues of dignity among family members. 
With the impact of the disaster, the districts are under pressure to source resources to respond to the affected households as many were already struggling to support the HH which were affected by the cyclone Ana.
Malawi Red Cross and the Department of Disaster and Management Affairs (DoDMA) in the districts and community-level structures are continuing to carry out Disaster Needs Assessment. However, basing on the preliminary reports it is already indicating that the below-mentioned interventions will be a priority:
o	Detailed disaster needs assessment 
o	Support to provision of food items to the affected beneficiaries  
o	Support to provision of shelter items to the affected beneficiaries 
o	WASH interventions to ensure good camp management practices are being followed

field_reports.description: Since the onset of the first cholera case in the season on 2nd March 2022 through Machinga district, Cholera cases have also reportedly occurred in Nsanje since 13th March, 2022. The cases have been increasing and as of 18th March 2022, a total of 7 cases (I in Machinga and 6 in Nsanje) have been registered. Cholera is an acute diarrheal infection caused by ingestion of food or water contaminated with the bacterium called “vibrio cholerae”. The main signs and symptoms of the disease are diarrhea with or without vomiting. The disease affects both children and adults if untreated and it can kill within hours. Cholera is more common during the rainy season. The Government of Malawi through the Ministry of Health has put measures in place to prevent and control spread of the outbreak by intensifying surveillance including contact tracing of the index case.

results.summary:
Malawi is currently experiencing one of the worst cholera outbreaks in years. The first case was registered in Machinga district in the Southern region of Malawi on 02 March 2022. The Malawi Ministry of Health declared the cholera outbreak on 03 March 2022 after the increase and spread of confirmed cases. The cholera outbreak, initially limited to the southern part of the country, has now spread to Malawi's northern and central regions. Cases climbed steadily throughout mid 2022, climbing rapidly towards the end of the year and into early 2023. The country continues to register new cholera cases in different parts of the country, with all districts affected. The fatality rate exceeds the acceptable threshold set by the WHO of less than 1%.

There is also spread to neighbouring Zambia, Mozambique, Tanzania and Zimbabwe where outbreaks are being declared.

The Malawi Red Cross report that there is an urgent need to address the risk factors of the outbreak, such as the provision of safe drinking water, especially in the hotspot areas. Several displaced communities in areas that were affected in 2022 by the cyclones Ana and Gombe are still living in precarious hygienic conditions. The drought and associated malnutrition that has affected vast areas of Malawi are making the communities, particularly children, more at risk of mortality due to the increased vulnerability caused by their poor nutritional status.

field_reports.summary: AN UPDATE ON CONFIRMED POLIO CASE IN MALAWI, 21 FEBRUARY 2022
field_reports.description:
The Ministry of Health has reported a confirmed Polio or Poliomyelitis case from Lilongwe districts (WHO Media Release, 17th February 2022). Poliovirus causes irreversible paralysis disease mainly in children zero to fifteen years of age. It also has a potential to infect immunocompromised adults. Normally a child would present to a health facility with acute onset of limb weakness which progresses to paralysis. If it is a leg or an arm, it may become relatively smaller (wasted) than the normal body mass and loses function because it is weaker than the rest of the body. 

It is a disabling and life threatening disease. Polio is an infectious disease and can be passed from one person to another through ingestion of food or water which is contaminated with polio virus. The high risk group are those that are unvaccinated or those that have received fewer doses of polio vaccines. 

The Ministry of Health with support from partners has put in place strategies for elimination of Polio in the Country. These strategies are in line with the strategies recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) through the Global Polio End Game Strategy. Vaccines are the most effective and available prevention strategy for this disease in addition to improved water and sanitation practices. Worldwide, we still have few countries mainly outside Africa where Wild Polio Virus type 1 is endemic.

The Malawi Government through the Ministry of Health established the National Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI) in 1979 to deal with vaccine preventable diseases including Polio, Measles and Neonatal Tetanus. These diseases are undergoing eradication and elimination. The Ministry has therefore intensified surveillance for these diseases in line with the WHO recommendations. Malawi has sustained good coverage of all its vaccine antigen above 80% now for two decades and polio vaccine is no exception. Like many other countries in the world, Malawi provides polio vaccine that targets Polio virus type 1 and type 3 following the eradication of Polio virus type 2 many years back. We are also vaccinating our children with Inactivated Polio Virus vaccine with sustained good coverage to date since introduction in 2018.

The Immunization program also joined the global efforts to eradicate polio completely and as such we have been implementing polio disease surveillance to ensure that we are able to pick any polio case within our communities and avoid further spread. Our partners like WHO, UNICEF and many others have been key stakeholders in strengthening the Global Polio Eradication Strategy. The last polio case in Malawi was reported in 1992 meaning that this is the first case in thirty years. Malawi also obtained a Polio free status in 2005 while the WHO African region received its Polio free status certificate in the year 2020. 

These are remarkable milestones in the polio eradication initiative in the country. In practice, any suspected child from zero to fifteen years of age coming with acute onset of flaccid paralysis or weakness is supposed to be reported as a suspected Polio case. The requirement is to report 2 non-polio AFP per 100000 as well as adequate stool specimen. Malawi has been meeting these indicators throughout the years and sustained its Polio surveillance robustly. The Ministry has in place Independent National Polio Expert Committees (National Expert Committee and the National Polio Certification Committee) which oversee and coordinate the polio surveillance and reporting system in the Country in line with the WHO recommendations.

In line with the WHO guidance and the International Health Regulations (IHR), the country is immediately putting in place additional activities in order to contain the situation in the Country. The first step is declaring this as a Public Health Emergency, the President on 17th February 2022, through the minister of Health declared a Public Health Emergency following confirmation of an imported case of polio in one of the districts There will be Emergence Operations Committee (EOC) meetings and a risk assessment of the situation will be done with support from our partners such as the WHO. We will also work very closely with our neighboring Countries and diseases know no borders.

As stated earlier, the laboratory results show that this is an imported virus as there is no evidence of community circulation of the virus. The Ministry of health has assured the nation that the situation is under control and would like to encourage the general public to continue observing good personal hygiene practice since the virus is spread through ingestion of contaminated food or water. The public has therefore been informed that the polio outbreak has been declared a Public Health Emergency by the Malawi Government.

2. Updates as of 21st February 2022

•	MoH has established an EOC at CHSU, TB Conference hall where different MoH departments and partners are meeting on a daily basis. MRCS is attending EOC meetings.
•	There is a global technical expert that has arrived in the country led by the Polio Technical International Committee to support Malawi in conducting surveillance and other interventions.
•	The EOC is conducting a Risk Assessment and a report is expected by Monday 21 Feb 2022
•	There is also a Social Working (RCCE) Group within the EoC that has been established to work on Social Mobilization activities among others social mapping/assessment and community engagement. The group has started developing a Social Behavioral Change and Communication Plan for Polio.
•	The group is also developing a Crisis Communication Plan with Key Messages on Polio that will guide Social Mobilization activities for the government and partners.
•	MRCS has joined the RCCE group where through Patrick and Dan and will start attending its meetings scheduled today at 10AM.
•	Besides, MRCS will keep on attending the EOC meetings starting today to keep on following on the way forward.
•	Round One for Bio PV: 31st March 2022 i.e. 6 weeks following Notification of a case. Pre implementation time frame ends on 30th March 2022 with a Launch slated for 30th March. Target Population for Mass Polio Vaccination: 0- 59 months.

3. Critical Needs
•	Media Briefing on Polio
•	Message Development-Pretesting, Key messages, Communication Materials- Posters, TV slots, Radio Jingles
•	District and community Briefing- Full Council Briefing, Area Development Committee, Traditional Leaders and Community briefing. 
•	Staff and Volunteer Orientation 
•	Dissemination of Polio messages through van publicity, radio, door to door by volunteers, radio jingles etc.
•	IEC materials
•	Volunteers supporting mass vaccination campaign
•	Infection Prevention

field_reports.summary: Malawi Disaster Alert: Strong winds and stormy rains
field_reports.description:
The Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services (DCCMS) issued a weather alert of strong winds and stormy rains. The alert indicated that the Southern and Central Regions of the country will be affected beginning early November 2021. Following the alerts a number of districts including Lilongwe, Mulanje, Mangochi, Chikwawa, Ntcheu, Machinga, Balaka, Zomba, Chiradzulu, Phalombe, Salima and Blantyre have already been greatly affected.  

So far, a total of 7,979 households have been affected. The Department of Disaster Management Affairs has registered 13 deaths (seven due to lightning strikes and six because of collapsed walls due to strong winds and stormy rains) and 51 injuries for the period July 2021 to November 19, 2021. Some of the affected households are being hosted by the families and neighbours within the communities. 

Furthermore, on 21st November 2021, the Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services (DCCMS) released a new warning, which cautioned Malawians to brace for heavy rains coupled with thunderstorms associated with destructive gusty strong winds, which will hit the South and gradually move to central and northern region parts of the country November 24 to Sunday, November 28, 2021.

Weather Alert!!!

Way forward
Based on the weather alerts, MRCS will continue to monitor the situation but also undertake the following anticipatory actions/ Early actions. The actions will seek to protect people before a disaster strike based on early warning or forecasts. In addition, MRCS will ensure that there is meaningful involvement and engagement of the communities at-risk. 



MRCS has been working with the Department of Disaster Management Affair and 4,180 households have been supported with Relief items, anticipatory messages, and activation of volunteers who have supported with capacity building in assessments, dissemination of alerts and support identification of evacuation centres as well as provision of early warning messages.
The glowing numbers of households being affected, the limited number partners supporting the response and the diminishing MRCS stocks compounded with the recent alert by DCCMS has resulted in MRCS being in high need of external support to address the current and future needs. 

It is against this background that MRCS intends to apply for DREF to strengthen its response capacity.
